talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on October 30 2000:

quote.para: (1) For each month since the stevedoring levy was introduced by the Government to facilitate the funding by the Maritime Industry Finance Company (MIFCO) of redundancy obligations by stevedoring companies as a result of the 1998 maritime dispute, what sum has been paid by each company liable to pay the levy.
(2) For each month since the levy was introduced, (a) what sum has been paid by MIFCO to each company eligible to receive payments and (b) how many employees has each company made redundant.
(3) Will some companies receive far less in payments from MIFCO than the levy they have paid; if so, what is the reason for the inequity.

(4) For each month since stevedoring companies were required to pay the levy, what has been the performance of companies receiving payments from MIFCO against the Government's productivity benchmarks compared to productivity levels at the time of the 1998 maritime dispute.

(5) Were any companies exceeding or equaling the Government's benchmarks in advance of the 1998 Maritime dispute; if so, (a) who were they, (b) are they required to pay the levy to assist non-performing stevedoring companies and (c) what payments have they made to MIFCO.

(6) Has the Government received complaints that some companies receiving MIFCO payments are using payments to offer artificial incentives to assist them in competition with other stevedoring companies.

(7) Has the Government been advised that Sea-Land believes Patricks has been able to use the levy payments to offer artificial incentives to South Australian exporters and importers to ship via Melbourne to have the disadvantage of South Australian operators; if so, does the accusation have any foundation.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The information on levy collected is considered `commercial-in-confidence', as the data would provide an accurate estimate of the market share of each stevedore.
(2) The following table shows the payments made by MIFCO in relation to each company.

para.inline: Number of Redundant Employees and Amounts Paid to 30 June 2000

entry.para: Freport Maintenance & Engineering Services Pty Ltd
Keon Cargo Stevedoring Pty Ltd (in liquidation) trading as Total Stevedores

quote.para: (3) The total levy to be paid by most stevedoring companies and all of the major stevedores will exceed their payments from MIFCO. There is no inequity under the provision of the Stevedoring Levy (Collection) Act 1998 as the levy is applied on a universal basis until all costs have been recovered. These costs cover not only the cost of redundancies, but also the interest on MIFCO loans.

(4) Performance benchmarking is undertaken on a port by port basis. The productivity benchmark of 25 lifts per hour is close to being achieved as a national five port average. The five port crane rate average for the September quarter was 24.9 as recorded in the Bureau of Transport Economics Waterline. This is in contrast to the five port crane rate average for the June 1998 quarter of 18.7.
(5) See answer to (1), (3) and (4).
(6) Yes.
(7) The use of `artificial incentives' is a matter for the ACCC to determine and Sea-Land have been advised to pursue that avenue.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) In light of statements made in the Australian Financial Review of 3 October 2000 in respect of the Western Sydney Orbital Link, what is the Government's estimate of the cost of the Western Sydney Orbital Link.
(2) What route is envisaged for the Western Sydney Orbital Link.
(3) Is he able to say whether the Western Sydney Orbital Link funding is predicated on a second Sydney airport being located at Badgery's Creek.

(4) Is he able to say whether assumptions about the rate of return on investment in the Western Sydney Orbital Link depend on estimated traffic flow arising from the location of a second Sydney airport at Badgery's Creek.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The current estimated cost, provided by NSW RTA, of the Western Sydney Orbital Link is $1.25 billion.

(2) The 39 km proposed corridor for the Western Sydney Orbital Link, from the M5 Motorway at Prestons near Liverpool to the M2 Motorway/Pennant Hills Road at West Baulkham Hills, was identified in the Roads and Traffic Authority of NSW brochure “The Western Sydney Orbital Overview Report - Starting the environmental assessment”. The corridor would be located between existing and proposed suburbs, utilising open space and services corridors extending from Hoxton Park in the south to Eastern Creek (or the M4) in the north. North of the M4 it would largely be accommodated in the Phillip Parkway and Castlereagh Expressway road reservations (NSW Roads and Traffic Authority 1998). The route will not be finalised until the EIS process is completed.
(3) and (4) The Western Sydney Orbital link is not predicated on a second Sydney airport being located at Badgery's Creek.

subdebateinfo.title: Australia and New Zealand: Monetary and Currency Union
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2052)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 472 (Hansard, 10 September 1996, page 3919), what communications have occurred between the Government and the New Zealand Government regarding monetary and currency union.
(2) On what terms and conditions does the Government support monetary and currency union.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) There has been significant public debate in New Zealand over the past year or so on the issue of currency union with the US or Australia. Reflecting this debate, discussion of the issue has occurred between the Government and the New Zealand Government as part of more general discussions.

For example, during the Prime Minister and Prime Minister of New Zealand's joint press conference on 28 September 2000, the Prime Minister, Mr Howard noted that the issue had been raised in their discussions. The Prime Minister went on to say that, “it's not something that Australia will be seeking to make the running on.”

(2) The Australian Government is not in favour of a new or third currency. Current monetary and macroeconomic policy arrangements in Australia have proven effective in providing the economic environment for the strong, low inflation growth and declining unemployment that we have seen in recent years. Were we to receive a request to adopt our currency arrangements, the Government would have a look at such a request. No such request has been received.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to his answer to questions No. 578 (Hansard, 18 November 1996, page 7035) and No. 3058 (Hansard, 15 July 1998, page 6263), does the Government plan to produce budget estimates on an expenditure tax basis.
(2) Would this allow the Government to publish figures regarding the net budget contribution to national savings.
(3) Does the Government's Charter of Budget Honesty or other budget guidelines currently require the publication of figures showing the net budget contribution to national savings.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (2) The net budget contribution to national savings is determined by both the level of public savings directly contributed towards national savings, and the effect that budgetary policies have on private savings' contribution towards national savings.
The fiscal budget balance represents the Commonwealth's direct contribution to the national savings and investment imbalance, which in turn approximates the nation's current account deficit.

From a national perspective, movements in government savings may be partially offset by changes in private saving. However, the extent of any such offset will depend on behavioural responses that are uncertain and are likely to vary considerably depending on the nature of the budgetary measures affecting the balance. It is not apparent that the use of any alternative basis for budget estimates would provide an accurate estimate of the net impact of the budget on national saving.
(3) The Charter of Budget Honesty requires government to frame fiscal policy in accordance with principles of sound fiscal management (which includes national savings).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 October 2000:

quote.para: With respect to the Ipswich Motorway, (a) at what stage is the major upgrade concept planning and (b) when is it expected that the Government will proceed with the major upgrade to relieve congestion and improve safety on the motorway.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (a) and (b) The Federal Government has provided $2 million towards the development of a concept plan for major upgrading of the Ipswich Motorway. This work will be undertaken in 2 phases. Phase 1 will establish the most appropriate standard for the Motorway in general terms, and involves disseminating information and gathering technical data. Phase 1 is now underway and Queensland Department of Main Roads (QDMR), who are undertaking this work on behalf of the Commonwealth, expect it to be completed by March 2001. Following this, Phase 2 will seek participation from key stakeholders and broader community consultation.

(b) QDMR expect the planning processes to be completed and a preferred upgrading concept to be identified by June 2002. Funding for construction of this project is still to be allocated, and will be considered in future National Highway works programs for Queensland.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 30 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) What was the outlay for payment of the adjustment to Commonwealth superannuants falling due on the first payday after 1 July 2000.
(2) What is the anticipated outlay for payment of the adjustment to Commonwealth superannuants falling due on the first payday after 1 July 2001.

(3) Has the Government made provision for advance GST compensation to be paid to public sector superannuants relative to their superannuation pensions as has been the case for other pensioners; if not why not.
(4) What would the outlay be for the 4% pensioner GST compensation to be paid to public sector superannuants for (a) Commonwealth, (b) State and (c) Territory superannuants.
(5) Did the Government index public sector superannuation pensions in advance of the predicted 1.9% CPI increase as a result of the introduction of the GST; if not, why not.
(6) What is the estimated cost of indexing public sector superannuation pensions to Male Total Average Weekly Earnings.
(7) Why are public sector superannuation pensions not indexed on a 6 monthly basis like other pensions.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Around $2 million per pension payday in 2000-01 for CSS and PSS pensioners.
(2) This will depend upon a number of factors including the percentage increase in the CPI between March 2000 and March 2001.
(3) Commonwealth superannuation pensioners are self-funded retirees and as such can benefit from The New Tax System on the same basis as all other self-funded retirees.

(4) This has not been costed for Commonwealth superannuants, as they are self-funded retirees. The GST compensation was available to social welfare recipients only. Many Commonwealth superannuants are entitled to a whole or a part age or other social welfare pension and would have received all or part of that compensation in respect of that pension. Questions about State and Territory superannuants need to be directed to the relevant State or Territory Government.
(5) No. Commonwealth superannuation pensioners are self-funded retirees and as such can benefit from The New Tax System on the same basis as all other self-funded retirees.

(6) The cost of changing the indexation of CSS/PSS pensions to MTAWE will depend upon the difference between CPI and MTAWE in any year. Based on the CSS/PSS liability at 30 June 1999, such a change is estimated to increase the present value of the Commonwealth's CSS/PSS unfunded liability by around $6.6 billion if an ongoing 1.5% difference is assumed or, by $4.1 billion if a 1% difference is assumed.

(7) Annual indexation is a method of indexation applied to a number of other pensions, including those paid by some State and Territory superannuation schemes. Annual indexation has been provided for in Commonwealth superannuation schemes since 1973 and forms part of the original scheme design of both the CSS and the PSS.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Safety Concerns
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2093)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 October 2000:

quote.para: Further to the answer to question No. 1744, will he update the progress of the review being undertaken by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority in conjunction with the Australian Transport Safety Bureau and Airservices Australia.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has determined that air traffic control should not nominate a runway for use when there is a crosswind of more than 20 knots and an alternative runway is available. The new crosswind limit will apply to all airports with more than one runway, including Sydney Airport.

CASA has also determined that Airservices Australia must provide pilots with an update of wind conditions when it issues takeoff and landing clearances, except at GAAP airports where the large number of aircraft in the circuit would make it impractical.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) What items of electronic/electrical equipment were used between 1969 and 1973 by a person who was training as an air electronic officer to operate Neptune and HS748 aircraft.
(2) What items of electronic/electrical equipment were used by an air electronic officer who served on Neptune and HS748 aircraft between 1969 and 1973.
(3) What were the radiation emission levels from the electronic/electrical equipment used during training.
(4) What were the emission levels from the electronic/electrical equipment used on the Neptune and HS748 aircraft between 1969 and 1973.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) During the period identified, Royal Australian Air Force air electronic officers undertook basic airmanship and radio communications training on the HS748 aircraft. They then undertook specific training on, and subsequently used, anti-submarine warfare equipment fitted to the Neptune aircraft. Only limited information exists on the electronic/electrical equipment fitted to the Neptune as it was withdrawn from service in the mid 1970s. The main equipment fitted to each aircraft used by air electronic officers is as follows:
HS748
HF 618T Radio
Neptune
- AN/APS20 Radar
- AN/AQA4 Jezebel Acoustics Set
- DT-37/ASQ-8 Magnetic Anomaly Detector
- AN/ASA20 Julie Acoustic Sensor
- ARC-92 HF Radio

(3) and (4) Of the foregoing, the most significant item in terms of emitted energy would be the Neptune radio. Due to the time that has expired, however, information on emission levels is not readily available. As there is no certainty that extensive archival research will yield this data, in the interests of efficient use of departmental resources, I am not prepared to authorise the time and effort required to provide this information.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is it the intention of his Department to destroy pay records relating to (a) current and (b) former Defence personnel; if so, which records are to be destroyed.
(2) What mechanism will his Department have to validate pay details of current and former defence personnel.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (b) Yes. The Department of Defence intends to destroy paper pay records of former Defence service personnel relating to the post World War II period. There is an agreement with National Archives of Australia to retain permanently pay records up to 1950, particularly including the two World Wars.

After pay records are destroyed, pay related information can still be reconstructed from details recorded on the member's personnel file.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 8 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) In relation to the announcement on 31 October of the sale process of the Essendon Airport, what are the guidelines and parameters to the development of the site referred to in objective (iv).
(2) Are majority foreign owned companies precluded from purchasing the airport.
(3) Will extra land around the airport be included in the sale process to make it safer.
(4) Are discussions being held with the Victorian Government in relation to possible changes in the alignment of the Tullamarine/Calder inter-change.
(5) Will the Government ensure that the new operator has emergency services on site 24 hours a day.
(6) Has the Government considered what impact a developed Essendon Airport will have on Tullamarine; if so, what will be that impact.
(7) How will possible purchasers demonstrate an awareness of environmental and local issues as required in objective (v).
(8) Is there a reserve price, or a price below which the Government will not accept a bid for the airport.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) As advised by my department, in consultation with DOTRS, Essendon Airport is to remain a general aviation airport to be regulated under the Airports Act 1996 with the development of the land to be in accordance with the lease provisions and that Act. Under the Act, the airport lessee is prevented from carrying on substantial trading or financial activities other than those relating to the operation and /or development of the Airport or that are incidental to the operation and /or development of the Airport. In the assessment of bids, attention will be paid to ensuring the proponent has an appropriate mix of financial strength and managerial capability to ensure that these requirements are likely to be met.
(2) As advised by my department, in consultation with DOTRS, the Airports Act 1996 precludes foreign ownership in the Airport in excess of 49%.

(3) As advised by my department, in consultation with DOTRS, Essendon Airport, like any other licensed aerodrome, is required to meet regulations and standards set by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) for the safe operation of an airport. In addition, CASA carries out compliance checks on the Airport's application of its standards. The Commonwealth proposes to sell its shares in Essendon Airport Limited, which currently leases the land occupied by the Airport, and there are no changes envisaged to the Airport's existing boundaries.

(4) As advised by my department, in consultation with DOTRS, I understand that Essendon Airport Limited management have had previous discussions with the Victorian Government in relation to possible changes in the alignment of the Tullamarine/Calder interchange. I am not aware of any current discussions between these parties.

(5) As advised by my department, in consultation with DOTRS, as is the case with all General Aviation Airports, Essendon Airport has no dedicated aviation rescue or fire fighting service. The Airport has well rehearsed Aerodrome emergency procedures developed in accordance with Civil Aviation Regulations and in consultation with Victoria Police, the Metropolitan Fire and Emergency Services Board, the Ambulance Service of Victoria and other agencies. Those procedures have local emergency services notified by Airservices Australia air traffic controllers when local fire, ambulance and police units are required at the Airport. They also provide for airport administrative arrangements to assist emergency services personnel attending, and operating on, the Airport. An Aerodrome Emergency exercise is held annually and the procedures are reviewed at least semi annually as well as after any live emergency or training exercises. These arrangements would continue under any new operator.

(6) As advised by my department, in consultation with DOTRS, the Government has considered what impact a developed Essendon Airport will have on Tullamarine. Essendon Airport will continue to cater principally for general aviation activities and emergency services such as Air Ambulance Victoria and the Victorian Police Air Wing. Current curfew and noise limitations will be formalised in Regulations. Essendon's operations will therefore continue to complement those at Tullamarine.

(7) As advised by my department, in consultation with DOTRS, the Airports Act 1996 and the Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations 1997 set out a comprehensive environment regulatory regime for the airport site. That regime includes the development and implementation of an approved airport environment strategy that sets out how the airport owner will operate the Airport to safeguard and improve the environment. Potential purchasers of shares in Essendon Airport Limited will need to demonstrate an understanding of the requirements of the environment protection regime and demonstrate a commitment to the implementation of the approved environment strategy for Essendon Airport.

(8) The Commonwealth does not set a reserve price for such sales. The Commonwealth will receive from its advisers as part of the sale process, valuation advice relating to Essendon Airport Limited which the Commonwealth will use as part of its assessment of bids against the sale objectives.

subdebateinfo.title: Superannuation: Pension and Allowance Means Test
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2156)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 27 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is superannuation required to be included in the pension means test for those over 55 years and 9 months, but below pension age; if so, what sum did the Government save in (a) 1997-98, (b) 1998-99 and (c) 1999-2000 by implementing this measure.
(2) How many individuals did the measure affect in (a) 1997-98, (b) 1998-99 and (c) 1999-2000.

(3) Since the inclusion of superannuation in the means test has the Retirement Income Modelling Task Force, or any other group, done modelling on the cost of this measure; if so, what are the results of the modelling.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Superannuation assets of customers below Age Pension age are assessed under the pension and allowance means test when the customer has received income support for a cumulative total of 39 weeks after reaching the age of 55.
(a) The administered savings amount from this measure in the 1997-98 year is calculated at $91.30 million.
(b) The administered savings amount from this measure in the 1998-99 year is calculated at $90.91 million.
(c) The administered savings amount for the 1999-2000 year is not yet available. This amount will be provided when it is available.

The above administered savings amounts are primarily based on information from Centrelink pension and allowance records. They are derived by a comparison of pension and allowance payments made to customers holding superannuation assets that are assessable under the measure with the payments that would have been made had these assets not been assessed.

This information was supplemented by some estimates, for example in regard to administered savings in respect of customers who did not claim a pension or allowance because the measure resulted in their having no entitlement to a payment, and who therefore do not appear on Centrelink records.
(c) The number of customers affected in the 1999-2000 year is not yet available. This number will be provided when it is available.
The above customer numbers have been derived in the same way as the administered savings amounts referred to in answer to part (1).

(3) I have been advised by the Treasurer that the Retirement Income Modelling Task Force has not done modelling on the cost of this measure. I am not aware of any modelling of the cost of the measure by other groups.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: It is anticipated that the passage of the Migration Legislation Amendment (Judicial Review) Bill 1998 would reduce the number of applications for review to the High Court in its original jurisdiction.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 27 November 2000:

quote.para: Further to his answer to a question without notice (Hansard, 8 November 2000, page 19803), and in relation to the increase in the number of applications under the Migration Act for judicial review in the Federal Court and the High Court, how would the passage of the Migration Legislation Amendment (Judicial Review) Bill 1998 reduce the number of applications for judicial review to the High Court in its original jurisdiction.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Migration Legislation Amendment (Judicial Review) Bill 1998 would lead to a reduction of applications.

It would align the jurisdiction of the Federal Court and the High Court, thereby making neither option more attractive. At present, people are applying to the High Court for review in an attempt to access grounds of review that have been excluded in the Federal Court by Part 8 of the Migration Act 1958.

The Bill implements a privative clause that would effectively expand the jurisdictional validity of decisions of the Migration and Refugee Review Tribunals. That clause would operate in an identical manner for both the Federal Court and the High Court. The clause would apply in accordance with the doctrine in R v Hickman; Ex parte Fox and Clinton (1945) 70 CLR 598.

subdebateinfo.title: Hong Kong: Canonisation of Chinese Catholic Martyrs
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2163)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to say whether, following the canonisation of 120 Chinese Catholic martyrs by Pope John Paul II, the Chinese Government has extended its denunciation of these canonisations to the ostensibly independent administrative region of Hong Kong.
(2) Are Australian representatives in contact with Bishop Joseph Zen, deputy ecclesiastic head of the Catholic Diocese of Hong Kong.
(3) Is he or the Australian High Commissioner able to confirm whether Beijing's Office of Liaison warned the Catholic Bishop to down play the canonisations.

(4) Is he able to say whether a Chinese language newspaper, the Ming Pao on Wednesday, 4 October 2000, reported of Chinas attitude to the Catholic Church in Hong Kong that Beijing is very dissatisfied with you.

(5) Has the Australian Government been in contact with the authorities in Beijing about this and other apparent attempts to interfere in the independent political and administrative region of Hong Kong.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I understand that, on 18 September, China's Central Government Liaison Office in Hong Kong met representatives from the Catholic Diocese of Hong Kong and requested that canonisation celebrations be kept “low key”.

(2) Our Consulate-General in Hong Kong is in contact with a range of human rights and religious organisations - including Roman Catholic representatives as senior as the ecclesiastical head of the Catholic Diocese of Hong Kong, Cardinal Wu. The Consulate-General provides regular reports on the implementation of `One Country, Two Systems' and the civil liberties situation in Hong Kong, including on freedom of religion.

(3) On 18 September, China's Central Government Liaison Office in Hong Kong met representatives from the Catholic Diocese of Hong Kong and requested that canonisation celebrations be kept “low key”. On 10 October, the Ming Pao newspaper reported Bishop Zen as saying that he did not consider the comments by the Central Government Liaison Office as constituting interference and that these comments had not impacted on religious freedom in Hong Kong.
(4) On 4 October, the Ming Pao published an open letter from Bishop Zen in which he quoted a mainland Bishop as warning him that “Beijing is very dissatisfied with you”.

(4) We continue to discuss with Beijing representatives the implementation of “One Country, Two Systems”, including civil and political rights, because this will be important for the continued success of Hong Kong as an international financial centre in which Australia has important interests.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to recent visit to Beijing by Ms Anson Chan, Secretary of the Hong Kong Administrative Region, to meet Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen.

(2) Is he able to say whether Ms Chan's meeting with the Chinese leader was followed by an admonition in the official Beijing newsagency Xinhua that the Hong Kong civil service headed by Ms Chan had been asked to better support Chief Executive Tung Chee Hua.

(3) How does the Australian Government interpret this criticism of Ms Chan and the independent civil service guaranteed under the One Country - Two Systems accord that is the basis of Hong Kong's relationship with China.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Australian Consulate-General provided a report on the visit at the time.

(2) A Xinhua press release after Mrs Chan's meeting with Vice Premier Chen reported Mr Qian as having “expressed his hope that Chan and all public servants in Hong Kong would better support the work of the Chief Executive and, under Tung Chee-hwa's leadership, continue to contribute to Hong Kong's prosperity and stability”.

(3) The Australian Government considers that the transition following China's resumption of sovereignty over Hong Kong and China's respect for Hong Kong's autonomy, as set out in the Basic Law, has generally proceeded smoothly. It will be important for Hong Kong's continued success as an international financial centre, in which Australia has important interests, that China should continue firmly to adhere to those commitments. Mrs Chan told the media that there was nothing new in Chinese leaders emphasising the importance of Hong Kong's civil servants supporting the Chief Executive. Mr Tung said that Mr Qian's intention had been to encourage civil servants because they were facing many pressures and challenges.

subdebateinfo.title: Renewable Energy Commercialisation Program: Hot Rock Energy
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2180)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 28 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Did the Australian Geological Survey Organisation (AGSO) release a study in 1994 indicating that clean energy resources, being geothermal power, capable of meeting Australia's total present energy needs for the next 830 years, had been found in two areas of the Artesian basin in South Australia.

(2) Has the Energy Research and Development Corporation said the AGSO study indicated Australia's total hot rock energy reserves would last the nation for 7500 years at present annual rates of all forms of energy.
(3) Will the Minister introduce legislation to conduct the necessary investigations required leading to the feasibility of harnessing this untapped clean energy.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) and (2) The study referred to by the Hon member for Lowe was conducted by officers of AGSO with funding support from the Energy Research and Development Corporation which released it for publication in November 1994.

The report concludes that “The calculated hot dry rock resources in favoured granite bodies beneath the Eromanga Basin amount to 2.5 million petajoules, 830 times Australia's current energy consumption.”

The report also assesses Australia's continental minimum hot dry rock energy resource (22.7 million petajoules) “...enough to supply all of Australia's needs at an annual consumption rate of 3000 petajoules, for 7500 years.” Current energy use is about 10 per cent above this level.

(3) Legislation will not enhance the process of harnessing energy from hot dry rock resources. It is a matter for further analysis and research into the technical and economic feasibility of developing hot rock energy in Australia. To this end, the Australian Greenhouse Office (AGO) has provided funding, under the Renewable Energy Commercialisation Program, of $1.79 million to two projects, which are currently investigating the feasibility of developing hot dry rock as a source of clean energy. Further details on these projects is provided on the AGO's web site: www.greenhouse.gov.au/renewable/recp/projects.html..

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 29 November 2000:

(3) On what occasions has the Sydney Opera House been considered for inscription on the World Heritage List.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) (a) Before the consideration of the Greater Blue Mountains Area at the 24th annual Session of the World Heritage Committee (27 November - 2 December 2000, Cairns), Heard and McDonald Islands and Macquarie Island were considered at the 21st annual Session of the World Heritage Committee, 1997. The Committee inscribed each of these properties on the World Heritage List.

(b) Kakadu National Park was considered by the World Heritage Committee for inscription on the List of World Heritage in Danger at the Committee's 3rd Extraordinary Session, held 12 July 1999. The Committee decided not to inscribe the property on this List.
(2) See my answer to Question 1(a).

(3) A World Heritage nomination for the property: `Sydney Opera House in its setting with the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the surrounding waterways of Sydney Harbour from Bradley's Head to McMahon's Point' was submitted to UNESCO on 31 December 1980. The nomination was considered by the executive of the World Heritage Committee, the World Heritage Bureau, at its 5th Annual Session, held 4-7 May 1981. The Bureau recommended to the Committee that the nomination be deferred and not inscribed on the World Heritage List. The Australian government then withdrew the nomination, in advance of the Committee's consideration.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 30 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many persons under the age of 18 have been held in detention centres in 2000.
(2) What has been the average length of stay for persons under the age of 18 in detention centres.
(3) How many persons under the age of 18 have been held in adult compounds rather than family quarters.
(4) Have any persons under the age of 18 knowingly been detained in adult compounds where they do not have a close relative.
(5) On how many occasions have close family groups been separated in detention centres.
(6) What priority is given to providing family accommodation to detainees arriving at the (a) Curtin, (b) Darwin and (c) Woomera Centres.
(7) Are detention centres subject to State laws.
(8) What procedures are there for detainees or staff at detention centres to lodge complaints with State Government agencies.
(9) Are detainees routinely prohibited from communicating with media representatives; if so why.
(10) Are any agencies independent of the Commonwealth Government permitted to investigate and report on conditions in detention centres; if so, which agencies.
(11) Have any complaints alleging sexual abuse been made by detainees at the Villawood Detention Centre; if so, were the complaints referred to the appropriate NSW authorities.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) 914 minors have been held in detention centres during 2000 until 14 December.

(2) At 14 December, there were 210 minors in detention. Of these 46% have been in detention for less than three months, 38% have been in detention for greater than three months but less than twelve months and 16% have been in detention for greater than twelve months.

(3) Families are generally accommodated in separate buildings in most detention centres. At the Villawood centre there are, however, two separate compounds. Stage 1 and Stage 1.5 are for adult males only; and families and minors are housed in Stage 2.

(4) Refer to previous answer. Prior to 22 February 2000, a number of young people (16,17 year olds) have at some time been accommodated in Stage 1 of Villawood. Since that date, this no longer happens.

(5) This is not information which is collated by the Department. There are, however, circumstances where family groups may be separated. These include where family members may arrive on different boats and therefore may be accommodated in different centres. On occasions when the Department has become aware of this, the Department has moved close family members together in one centre. Other circumstances include: when a member of a family is transferred to prison or to another area within the centre as a result of actions by them which may be a threat to the security of the centre; or where they are charged with an offence; or where they are at risk of self harm or of harming other detainees or staff.
(6) There is no detention facility in Darwin. Priority is always given at Curtin and Woomera, as it is at all the detention centres, to appropriately house families.

(7) The power to detain is derived from the Migration Act (1958). It is a requirement of the Immigration Detention Standards, which form part of the detention contract, that detention facilities are managed in a manner that is consistent with relevant Commonwealth and State/Territory laws.

(8) Specific procedures are in place for detainees to make direct contact with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission and the Commonwealth Ombudsman. There are no specific procedures for detainees to lodge complaints with State Government agencies. However, detainees are able to contact whoever they like, including State Government Agencies, once initial screening has been completed and they are accommodated with the general detainee population within their centre. In addition, staff are able to contact State Government agencies direct and indeed in some cases have mandatory reporting obligations.

(9) Detainees are able to contact whoever they like, including the media, once initial screening has been completed and they are accommodated with the general detainee population within their centre. Until this occurs, detainees have limited communication opportunities outside the centre. This is done in order to preserve the integrity of the refugee assessment process.

(10) Immigration Detention Centres are subject to external scrutiny through the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission and the Commonwealth Ombudsman. In addition, the Joint Standing Committee on Migration has also visited immigration detention facilities and recently published a report concerning these centres, Not the Hilton.
(11) In April 2000, there was an allegation of sexual abuse by a detainee against another detainee. The matter was referred to NSW police for investigation.

subdebateinfo.title: Veterans: National Memorial to Australian Servicemen
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2234)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 7 December 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has he had discussions with Veterans groups regarding the construction of a national memorial to Australian servicemen who served in Malaya and Borneo; if so, with which groups.
(2) Will the Government construct such a memorial; if so, what is the timeframe.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) There has been no discussion with veterans groups concerning the construction of an Australian national memorial to service in Malaya and Borneo.

(2) The Government acknowledges that national memorials of this nature play an important part in recording the service and sacrifice of Australians at war. The existing memorials in Anzac Parade in Canberra form an impressive commemorative axis from the Australian War Memorial to Lake Burley Griffin and Parliament House. This axis is a key feature of Walter Burley Griffin's original 1912 plan for Canberra.

It is not the role of the Government to construct these national memorials. My role, in conjunction with the National Capital Authority and other arms of government, is to examine proposals to ensure that the standards comply with those envisaged in Burley Griffin's plan. The completed work would need to be of notable design and of lasting quality to minimise maintenance and add value to the existing memorials of Anzac Parade.

Proposals for new memorials need an active organisation able to attract sufficient public support to raise the necessary funds for the construction. Recent examples of new memorials include the Australian Service Nurses National Memorial and the Australian National Korean War Memorial. In each case very active committees were formed and State Government and veteran organisations provided strong financial support. While considerable Federal Government financial assistance was still necessary when public fund-raising failed to meet the target in each case, this form of support cannot be relied upon for future memorials.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 7 December 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is he aware of a report prepared in 2000 by the Office of Small Business (OSB) on the impact of the Cabinet decision about the importation of second hand motor vehicles; if so, (a) why was the report commissioned, (b) who authorised the commissioning of the report and (c) when was the report provided to the Government.
(2) Did the low volume industry assist in the preparation of this report; if so, has OSB provided a copy to the low volume industry; if not, why not.
(3) Will he table the report in Parliament.
(4) Was the report required because the Regulatory Impact Statement on the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 identified a threat of significant small businesses closures in this industry.
(5) Does the report recognise the low volume industry as a major provider of jobs for small businesses throughout Australia.

(6) Will the Government revoke existing licences in May 2002 that were issued for the life of a model for vehicles no longer eligible under the Specialist and Enthusiast Vehicle Scheme (SEVS); if so, (a) why and (b) what compensation will be offered to the low volume industry.

talker.name: Reith, Peter, MP
Mr Reith
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) (a) to (c) After discussions with the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, it was agreed that the Office of Small Business (OSB) (in consultation with the Ministers' Departments) should report on the impact on small business of the Government decision to replace the Low Volume Scheme (LVS) with the Specialist and Enthusiast Vehicle Scheme (SEVS). The OSB reported on 8 August 2000.

(2) The OSB consulted the relevant industry organisations representing low volume importers in developing the report. The report was prepared to assist Ministers in their deliberations and was not made available to other parties interested in the SEVS decision.
(3) The report was a report to Ministers on a specific issue and it is not proposed for it to be tabled.
(5) The report is confidential.

(6)(a) The Government is providing a 2 year transitional period to May 2002. Holders of approvals after the transitional period will need to re-apply for assessment against the SEVS criteria. Vehicle models that satisfy the new criteria will continue to be eligible.

(6)(b) No compensation is available for those involved in the new arrangements. The Government is assisting to minimise any disruption from the introduction of the new scheme. Specific duty and regulatory concessions are carried over to SEVS.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 7 December 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2056 (Hansard, 27 November 2000, page 20085), do the oil terminal access regimes the Minister has referred to deny access to all those market participants who have a supply agreement with one of the country's four major oil companies.
(2) If so, what proportion, by volume, of petrol flowing through Australia's terminals is sold to those who are in a supply agreement with one of the four major oil companies.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) No. Market participants' right of access to terminals is determined by the factors outlined in the answer to question No. 2056, including safety and environmental requirements. The nature of supply agreements between the four major oil companies and other market participants varies depending on the commercial arrangements between the parties. Some supply agreements include delivery of fuel by the oil company. Other supply agreements are based on collection of fuel from terminals. talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss Jackie Kelly
talker.role: Minister for Sport and Tourism and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Government allocated a record $360.9 million, over four years to The Government allocated a record $360.9 million, over four years to 2001-02, to the Australian Tourist Commission to bolster Australia's position in the international market place. It has delivered on the third instalment of this record funding by allocating in excess of $91 million to the ATC in the 2000-01 Budget.

Latest overseas arrivals figures confirm that the ATC is continuing to do an excellent job in promoting Australia overseas. subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force: Retirements and Redundancies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2249)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister of Defence, upon notice, on 7 December 2000:

quote.para: In relation to the investigation conducted by Commodore Ken Birrer into a number of management initiated early retirements and voluntary redundancies involving Defence Force officers, (a) what prompted the commissioning of the review, (b) what were the terms of reference of the review, (c) how many separate cases were investigated, (d) what was the total value of the payouts made to the officers involved, (e) on what date was the final report of the review submitted to Defence, (f) what were the findings and conclusions made by Commodore Birrer and (g) what action has the Government taken in response to the report.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (a) The Chief of the Defence Force (CDF) commissioned the Birrer review after taking into consideration concerns raised publicly with regard to a case of possible inappropriate use of management initiated early retirement (MIER).
(b) Legal advice remains extant that the terms of reference should not be publicly released.
(c) All the cases of MIER and voluntary redundancy (VR), for which full documentation was available, were examined. Specifically this amounted to 28 cases of MIER and 159 cases of VR.
(d) It is not possible to provide an accurate figure for the 187 cases examined by the review.
(e) The final report was submitted on 1 November 1999.

(f) Legal advice remains extant that the review should not be publicly released. However, Air Commodore Birrer did find that in general the MIER and VR programs had been managed in accordance with policy and administered appropriately, although, he recommended that ADF policy on the application of MIER and VR be amended.
(g) The Government accepted the recommendations and CDF Directive 1/2000, dated 23 March 2000, details the ADF policy on the application of MIER and VR.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 7 December 2000.

quote.para: (1) Does privacy legislation allow the release of information in conformance with information privacy principles that would permit the release of information in the public interest.

(2) Do spouses, sponsors and those placing bonds for and on behalf of visa applicants have a public interest to information otherwise denied for release under privacy law or statutory provisions under the Migration Act; if not, will he amend the existing migration legislation that permits a spouse, sponsor or those placing bond monies, a right to access information relating to the visa applicant for the purposes of granting them limited rights to access to information regarding the visa applicant.
(3) What percentage of spouse visa applicants result in separation or divorce from their sponsors after the two years provisional spouse condition on their visa.
(4) What percentage of spouse visa applications are marriages of convenience.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answers to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Information Privacy Principle 11 of the Privacy Act 1988, which limits the disclosure of personal information, states that:

“1. A record-keeper who has possession or control of a record that contains personal information shall not disclose the information to a person, body or agency (other than the individual concerned) unless:
(a) the individual concerned is reasonably likely to have been aware, or made aware under Principle 2, that information of that kind is usually passed to that person, body or agency;
(b) the individual concerned has consented to the disclosure;

(c) the record-keeper believes on reasonable grounds that the disclosure is necessary to prevent or lessen a serious and imminent threat to the life or health of the individual concerned or of another person;
(d) the disclosure is required or authorised by or under law; or
(e) the disclosure is reasonably necessary for the enforcement of the criminal law or of a law imposing a pecuniary penalty, or for the protection of the public revenue.”

(2) The concept of “public interest” is given different applications in various areas of decision making, depending on the legislative or administrative purposes involved. It relates to concerns of the general community as a whole rather than just to a private individual.

In spite of the fact that such public interests may exist in the community, neither the Privacy Act nor the Migration Act makes any provision for the disclosure of personal information to someone else on the grounds of public interest.

DIMA officers are already permitted to make certain disclosures of visa applicant information to sponsors, as explained in Administrative Circular 198 “Privacy Act 1988: Disclosure of personal information to third parties”. This advises that limited information of the visa applicant may be disclosed to the nominator / sponsor in accordance with Information Privacy Principle 11.1.a:

“10.1 Where a sponsor, or a Member of Parliament (including a Member's staff) acting on behalf of a sponsor, seeks access to personal information of an applicant, only as much information may be disclosed as the applicant would be reasonably likely to expect would be disclosed to the sponsor (that is, IPP 11(1)(a) applies). Personal information which it would be reasonable to disclose in response to inquiries from sponsors or from Members of Parliament acting on their behalf includes:

answer.para: · whether application has been lodged;
· stage reached;
· points awarded;
· decision made; and

· if rejected, reasons for that decision, unless they are of a personal or sensitive nature. Assessments based on occupational considerations, for example, would not normally give rise to privacy concerns. Assessments based on health or character, however, would normally be regarded as sensitive and details would not normally be released without the consent of the applicant.

quote.para: 10.2 Certain general information is non-personal in nature and can be disclosed. Such information includes:

answer.para: · advice on processing times;
· advice on requirements which apply to a particular visa class;
· passmark, pooling provisions, etc.”

quote.para: To make additional disclosures, the visa applicant's consent must be obtained (Information Privacy Principle 11.1.b), or the sponsor may ask the visa applicant directly for the information. There is no intention to amend the Migration Act to authorise such disclosures of a visa applicant's personal information to a sponsor on the grounds of public interest.

(3) A breakdown of the specific reasons for refusal of a permanent (second stage) Spouse visa is not available, however, anecdotally most spouse applications are refused because applicants no longer meet the spouse definition of the Migration Regulations due to the breakdown of the relationship.

Data on the total number of persons who are refused the grant of permanent (second stage) Spouse visa is an indicator of the number of relationships that cease due to separation or divorce. Spouse visa applicants at the permanent stage may be refused for a number of reasons including failure to meet the health and character requirements; and no longer being in a continuing and genuine spouse relationship.

For the Program Year 1999-2000, of the 9,500 decisions made on applications for a permanent Spouse visa where the spouse was granted a provisional (first stage) visa at an overseas post, less than 4 percent were refused the permanent (second stage) visa. A further 3 percent of holders of the provisional visa elected to withdraw their application for the permanent Spouse visa before a decision was made.

(4) The overall Spouse visa (first stage) refusal rate of 14 per cent for offshore and 9 per cent for onshore lodged cases for the 1999-2000 Program year would mostly reflect refusals on the grounds that a delegated decision-maker did not consider the relationship to be genuine and ongoing.
